event.description:
THIS CLASS IS HELD ON-LOCATION AT THE INSTRUCTOR'S STUDIO IN OAKLAND, IT IS NOT HELD AT LOOKING GLASS.

If you are ready to delve deeper into lighting, this is your class! A further study in how light can give people and objects enhanced presence in photographs. Critical custom light balance will be taught & placement of lights and reflectors will be studied.

Students come out with a box of tools for photographing people and things. You’ll have a shorter first day, introducing you to ideas and showing pictures. Your second day will be 8-hours of demos and hands-on experience. Your third day, more hands-on practice, comes a week later after you’ve digested the info.

*This is a 3-session class.

Instructor: Dana Davis
Minimum: 6 students
Dates: 1/11 6-8pm, 1/12 & 1/19 10am-6pm
Price: $300

event.description:
Pack your sweaters, tripods, & remote releases for a trip to Treasure Island at dusk! This on-location class is great for beginning & advanced, film & digital shooters. You’ll get info in brief spiels throughout a night of hands-on practice.

Topics include: composition, ISO noise, magic hour lighting & the afterglow effect. You’ll use long exposures to capture movement & shorter exposures too. Mike will help you capture dynamic portraits, with & without flash. You’ll learn the settings & equipment needed for especially long exposures & techniques for painting with light.

Date: 2/12 5-8pm

event.description:
image from Looking Glass Photo Pinhole Day Workshop, 2010. courtesy of Jon Freel

The expert staff of Looking Glass will be on hand to help you make a pinhole camera, or you can bring your already-made camera by the store for all-day fun!

We’ll be constructing & shooting pinhole cameras & developing the resulting images in our darkroom. No previous darkroom experience necessary, we will be there to help you with every step in the process! If you plan on building a camera, please bring a light-tight container to convert into a camera (cookie or tea tins work great!). We will provide everything else that you need to make your pinhole camera. For those folks who want to keep it digital and own a DSLR we will also have a number of pinhole conversion options available for purchase and some you can borrow just for the event!

We’ll have interesting props for you to shoot, or you can wander the neighborhood and find a scene that looks interesting to you. Participants are welcome to come anytime and stay as long (or as short) as they like. We do recommend that workshoppers plan on staying for at least an hour to optimize their pinhole image making success!

Fee for the event covers all materials & instruction, and we will scan & upload the image of your choice to the online WPPD online gallery for all the world to see!

Feel free to stop by the store before the event (or anytime) and ask us all your pinhole photography questions, we’ll be ready & willing to answer! And if you’d rather do pinhole photography on your own, or just want to be really prepared for the big day, we have a large supply of pinhole cameras and accessories available at the store for purchase.

Instructor: LG Staff
Date: 4/28 11am-4pm
Price: $10 for adults, $5 for kids 12 & under

event.description:
Are you tired of having back or joint pain? You can learn how to be free of pain! Learning what is the underlying cause of your pain will enable you to make changes that eliminate your pain. Almost everyone in highly industrialized countries has adopted a modern posture that is misaligned and so pervasive we can't even see it. Many treatments don't address the underlying cause of pain.

Learning a set of simple, specific guidelines can bring you relief from pain anytime, anywhere. The same guidelines that take away your pain also straighten your spine.

Come to a 2 hour Balance Method workshop - "The 3 Myths That are Causing Your Back Pain".

IN BERKELEY: Saturday, January 12, 2013 from 6-8 pm.

RESERVATIONS ARE REQUIRED. Seating is limited.  Cost is $10.  If you register for the Balance Your Body program, you may deduct your $10 ticket fee from the tuition due.

Why do people in some countries have no back pain? 80% of the population in the United States suffers from back pain, compared to only 5% in many other countries, such as Portugal and Greece. These healthy people move slightly differently than we do. The teaching of the Balance Center is based on more than 35 years of research on these healthy populations. When you stand, bend, sit, walk, and sleep as these people do, your pain can be significantly reduced or eliminated.

SIX WAYS THIS APPROACH IS UNIQUE:

-Balance is based on studying healthy people
-No special devices, special equipment or special chairs are needed
-No exercises or radical positions are required
-Balance dramatically improves your posture
-You use this information immediately in your car, at work, even at the
movies
-A slight shift in position brings relief


WHAT DO PEOPLE SAY ABOUT THE RESULTS OF BALANCE?

“I have successfully used Balance Center instructions as part of a comprehensive treatment program for my patients with painful spinal conditions.”
- William Firtch, M.D.

"This class was a revelation for me. It increased my awareness of being out of Balance and I learned simple changes I can make to become more balanced and pain free. It was powerful learning what I can do on a daily basis to avoid pain. Dana taught us simple techniques to use everyday to correct bad posture and live pain free. It’s given me hope and has been a life changing experience that has put me back in control ."
- Julie Shapiro, Oakland, CA

“For 17 years I spent thousands of dollars for medical treatment and loss of work time to find a solution to relieve lower back pain due to an auto accident.  I sought treatment using acupuncture, acupressure, massage therapy, osteopathic and more.  These treatments were helpful for a short time, but it did not teach me the proper body mechanics for lifelong relief.  Surgery and continuous use of drugs was not a viable option.  The classes I took from Dana at Sonoma Body Balance were my saving grace.  I learned how to properly sit, sleep, walk, drive, bend, lift, etc.  I have not experienced any back pain since completing the classes."

-Wayland Lew

"Before I took the Balance class, I experienced chronic neck, low back, hip, and gluteal tension, in spite of the fact that I received weekly chiropractic adjustments. While taking the class, my tension decreased significantly. The tools I learned in the class also enabled me to teach basic sitting skills to patients which helped eliminate a major cause of recurring back pain for many of them."
-Jay Bunker, Chiropractor

Taught by Dana Davis, MA, Senior Certified Instructor by the Balance Center in Palo Alto and Certified Yoga Teacher. Class includes slides, practice sitting and bending in Balance, anatomy and individual hands-on guidance. Enrollment is limited. For more information, visit www.sonomabodybalance.com. For information about the Balance Center, visit www.balancecenter.com.


*** END PAIN AT THE SOURCE! ***

organizer.description: Sonoma Body Balance offers posture and yoga classes for people with back & joint pain and who want to avoid getting curvy and hunched as they get older. You learn simple movements to get pain free fast!
organizer.long_description: Dana Davis, MA, CYT, is a Senior Certified Balance Teacher by the Balance Center in Palo Alto, California, where she has studied and worked with Jean Couch (author of The Runner's Yoga Book) since 1996. She has practiced yoga since 1984 and is a graduate of the 3-year Advanced Studies Program at the Yoga Room in Berkeley (a 500-hour program). She has studied Restorative Yoga with Judith Lasater, and is a certified "Relax and Renew" Trainer. She has also completed advanced studies with Richard Miller, Ph.D., in Yoga Nidra/iRest. She has a B.A. in Psychology and an M.A. in Spirituality and was a professional Flamenco dancer for 7 years in San Francisco, performing twice in the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival. Sonoma Body Balance is an approved provider by the California Board of Registered Nursing (Provider #CEP 15643).
organizer.name: Sonoma Body Balance

event.description:
Finally the controversial and anticipated horror movie "The Cohasset Snuff Film" screening premieres in the Bay Area Thursday, December 13, 7:30pm - 9:20pmin Berkeley, CA atLandmark Shattuck Cinemas ( Block from Berkeley bart station)Only days left to get tickets. Please don't procrastinate and get your tickets now: http://www.tugg.com/events/2270

Film Synopsis:

In 2009, the small town of Cohasset, Massachusetts was rocked with tragedy. A 17-year-old high school senior named Collin Mason murdered three classmates. All the murders were videotaped. Collin uploaded the video to the Internet, and for three days, the world viewed the murders of these three innocent teens. Through legal action, the parents of the victims were able to remove all footage from the Internet. The impact of this video is still being felt in Cohasset today. Bootleg copies of this footage are still passed around and downloaded through illegal means. The video has become infamous, and is now referred to as The Cohasset Snuff Film.

Critics Reviews:

"The Cohasset Snuff Film is really everything it sets out to be -- it is a sickening and harrowing excursion into a dark and twisted mind -- it is the first time I've looked away from a horror film in quite some time -- and on top of that, the production is well executed"

"The Cohasset Snuff Film" is shocking and brutal to watch and over all, it achieves its purpose in becoming skin crawling and in offering an intriguing and watchable examination of the mind behind such horror." -Jesse Miller Morehorror.com

"The great thing about "The Cohasset Snuff Film" is its raw intensity. There are no jump scares or cheesy twists. It’s less of a descent into madness as it is being just thrown into the mix right before shit goes down—and shit does go down".

"This film is grounded in reality and the murders are real. Some mad props go to these actors who certainly had trust in director Edward Payson and believed in this project. Their trust will no doubt be rewarded as this film will certainly be getting some pretty big attention in the near future. I say that with no hesitation, because this film has all of the right pieces to be an underground hit".- L.A.HORROR

"A look into a serial killers mind and something that blows the horror genre wide open.This film is sure to cause some controversy".- Back At The Movies UK

"The Cohasset Snuff Film is one of the top five independent horror films we've seen this year" - Erik Vanlier Golden State Haunts

Past halloween world premiere, L.A. fans loved it! Nov. 8th Massachussette fans responded the same. Both crowds filled with questions about the film. after their screenings. #THECOHASSETSNUFFFILM

TRAILER: http://youtu.be/45uwNSYVtuk

event.description:
If online learning keeps you up at night (literally and/or figuratively), the Berkeley Center for New Media and the CITRIS Data and Democracy Initiative welcome you to join us for two days of lively discussion and debate around Critical Issues in Online Education. Whether you are a MOOC maniac or a pen-and-paper traditionalist, it is undeniable that information and communication technologies are rapidly transforming higher education. We are faced with urgent questions about the future of higher education and the opportunities, conditions, and tensions that emerge from on-campus and online settings. This highly anticipated conference will bring together interdisciplinary scholars, educational media developers, students, and employers to collaboratively explore, discuss, and advance shifting notions of tools, metrics, communities of practice, accreditation, and learning from a perspective of innovation and of concern for the future of higher education. Specifically, speakers will address issues such as theories of learning engagement, peer evaluation, online learning monetization, measuring learning online, and the flipped classroom. The objective of the conference is to identify key factors in successfully implementing innovative online and on-campus learning platforms. 

 

Pre-registration to one or both days is necessary, as tickets are limited. Registration is free and lunch will be provided for a nominal fee. All attendees also have the option of making a student's day by purchasing lunch for a student.

organizer.description: The Center for Information Technology Research in the Interest of Society (CITRIS) creates information technology solutions for many of our most pressing social, environmental, and health care problems.

organizer.long_description: La Pes a community cultural center with a national reputation and a global vision that promotes peace, social justice and cultural understanding through the arts, education and social action.As a welcoming gathering place, La Perovides opportunities for artists to share diverse cultural traditions, to create and perform their work, and to support and interface with diverse social movements.Annually, La Peresents over 200 events with emerging and established artists; organizes an arts education program; produces new works by local artists, presents internationally and nationally renowned artists, and houses a Latin American cafe which complements the organization's mission.

event.title: Flamencos por La Peña!

event.description:
A Benefit for La Peña with Gail Dobson's Vocals for Kids!, Hector Lugo's Puerto-Rican Ensemble & Josh Jones' Latin Jazz Orchestra

 

Gail Dobson's class, "Vocals for Kids", would like to share with you their love of singing and performance. Come witness this and be prepared to be smilin' from ear to ear!!

The Puerto Rican Music Ensemble, formed by students and directed by Héctor Lugo, performs traditional and original pieces inspired by the popular and folkloric music of Puerto Rico: plena, bomba, seis, aguinaldo, danza, guaracha jíbara, and more.

The La Peña Latin Jazz Orchestra has been ongoing for the past 14 years under the direction of Bay Area drummer & percussionist, Josh Jones. The band explores all styles of Latin Jazz and Salsa with a focus on reading, interpretation, and improvisation. It's a great environment to hone your latin music skills, whether you're an instrumentalist, percussionist, or vocalist. The La Peña Latin Jazz Orchestra will be performing at this benefit for La Peña paying tribute to Latin Jazz greats such as Eddie Palmieri and Ray Barretto. Please come out and support this event that will help sustain La Peña Cultural Center, which is a vital part of our community.

All proceeds will support La Peña’s non-profit mission of promoting peace, social justice, and cultural understanding through the arts, education, and community action.

event.description:
BHS 1993/1992 GRADS: Please join us for a special evening, with old friends, at The Claremont Hotel Club and Spa in Berkeley, CA. You are sure to enjoy the spectacular views of San Francisco bay and the gourmet food stations prepared by our very own: Josh Ladd.  You won't want to miss this once in a lifetime event!

Ticket price includes:

  • a HOSTED cocktail hour
  • Unlimited use of a "Photo Booth"
  • DJ/music/dancing
  • MEMORIES - photos, slideshow video, memorabilia and more!
  • Spectaular views of San Francisco Bay


A Full Gourmet Dinner - meal stations include

 

  • Anti Pasti & Cheeses & Build your own Caesar Salad
  • 2 Pasta Stations
  • Dim Sum Station
  • Carving Station – Beef
  • Dessert & Coffee Station

**Special hotel rates are available for guests of the BHS Reunion.

The Claremont Website: 

http://www.claremontresort.com/

event.description:
This free class is a great way to find out what mindfulness is and how it can reduce stress and anxiety in daily life. The class includes lecture, discussion, experiential mindfulness practices, and a video program about Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn, founder of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR). This is also an opportunity to sign up for the 8-week MBSR class at Harmony Yoga beginning January 21. Though there is no obligation to do so.

If you plan on taking the 8-week class, it is highly recommended that you attend this orientation session.

organizer.description: A business that provides mindfulness meditation training throughout the San Francisco Bay Area. See Stress Reduction at Work for more details.

event.description:
One of the most respected masters and musicians within the son jarocho community, Andrés Flores Rosas comes to the Bay Area to present both old and new compositions as a soloist at La Peña. Featuring Bay Area artists, Andrés will take the stage, blending a mixture of sounds, from traditional sones to modern fusions. The night will also consist of holiday sones typically played during the months of December in Veracruz. Between the frenzied strumming of the jarana or the quick rift of a requinto, this night will prove to be unforgettable and a show not to be missed.

Originally from Alvarado, Veracruz, Andrés is a renowned luthier of son jarocho instruments, a musician and singer and is a specialist in playing the percussive instruments of the son jarocho. He has directed his own professional group (Quemayama) and heads his Taller Cascabel (a school). Andrés has been a member of the internationally renowned son jarocho groups “Chuchumbé” and “Quemayama”, both groups of the highest caliber and comprised of some of the most well known musicians of the son jarocho.  Both groups have recorded several CDs and have toured throughout Mexico, in the US, Europe, and Latin America. Over the last year, Andrés has toured in Colombia with “PianoXarocho“, as well as been a featured performer with his most recent project with “Sistema Bomb”.

Andrés has received several awards at the national level for his work as a luthier. His instruments are works of arts, each uniquely elaborated by hand.

event.description:
Parents, students and professionals are invited to attend this upcoming College Internship Program Open House Information Session to learn the latest about CIP, a comprehensive college and career program for young adults 18-26 on the autism spectrum and/or with learning differences.

Agenda will include the following:

  • Overview of the program and curriculum
  • Meet with students and staff
  • Guided tour of offices, classrooms and apartments
  • Time for individual questions

About CIP

Since 1984, the College Internship Program (CIP) has expanded to locations across the US. CIP's comprehensive curriculum and cutting-edge approach to developing real-world skills expands the foundation on which young adults with ASD and LD can build happy and productive lives.

organizer.long_description: CIP's full-year postsecondary programs provide young adults with Asperger's, High-Functioning Autism, ADHD, Nonverbal and other Learning Differences with the social, academic, career and life skills necessary for success. Our mission is to inspire independence and expand the foundation on which young adults can build happy and productive lives.
organizer.name: CIP Berkeley

event.title: CIP Berkeley Information Session

event.description:
You can't plan for a new beginning.

It often just happens without any warning or notice. There's no time for preparation. However, ifyou embrace it with an open heart and mind, everything can change for the better.

Ever since 2004, production powerhouse and platinum-selling eclectic pop unit The Cataracs had been a duo—Niles and Campa. However, in the summer of 2012, after the release of the sizzling hot Gordo Taqueria [Indie-Pop/Republic Records] and its fiery lead single "All You" featuring Kaskade and Waka Flocka Flame, Campa decided to follow a lifelong dream and travel the world, effectively leaving The Cataracs a one-man unit. Niles dusted himself off and kept forging ahead though.

"It left me really vulnerable and anxious for a minute," he admits. "It also gave me the opportunity to come into my own as a solo act and even realize the initial vision that I had for The Cataracs. I like creating intelligent dance music that makes people move. That's what I've wanted to do since the beginning. Campa and I weren't always on the same page about that. Now, I have an even clearer understanding of what The Cataracs is, and I'm making the best music I've ever made."

That's a bold claim, but it's true. From day one, Niles had served as the group's producer and produced other artists under the moniker "The Cataracs". He was behind the immortal beat for Far East Movement's "Like a G6" featuring Dev. The track became a worldwide phenomenon, surpassing digital sales of 3 million and topping the Billboard Hot 100. It also kick-started the
careers of Far East Movement and Dev and created unanimous demand for production from Niles.

From there, he worked the board for Dev's platinum smash "In the Dark" as well her entire major label debut, The Night the Sun Came Up, Snoop Dogg's saucy "Wet", and other tracks from the likes of Enrique Iglesias, Usher, 50 Cent, New Boyz, and more. He's also been sought out by everyone from E-40 to David Guetta.

At the same time, honing his two-prong vision for The Cataracs, he's pushing the boundaries of pop. On his solo material, he cooks up an infectious concoction of sexy dance music with lo-fi hip hop swagger and undeniable pop bliss. His forthcoming first single as a solo act "Roll the Dice" blazes to life.

Teaming up with production masters Stargate and electronic dance music stalwart Wolfgang Gartner, Niles created one of his most irresistible anthems to date. You'll definitely want to "Roll the Dice" with him.

"I wrote it when I was in Brazil," he remembers. "I brought in Stargate and Wolfgang Gartner in, and they made it even more dope. It's a love song, but it draws a lot of parallels to gambling. I'm really proud of it."

However, he hasn't stopped there. On another new cut, "Chinese Takeout", he's enlisted the talents of Anjulie and Petros, making for a seductive call-and-response between the singers fueled by his inimitable production style.

"I rented this house to work on music and I invited everybody up there," he goes on. "I want to bring together different artists under one banner. It's a boy and girl song, but the two-part melody is so hot."

The next chapter of The Cataracs has kicked off with a bang, and it's only just begun.

"I've got confidence like I've never had before," enthuses Niles. "I want fans to walk away from my music with something they're not getting anywhere else. I want to give people addictive, catchy songs. That's what I love to do."

organizer.description: The Jazzschool is an innovative music school dedicated to the study and performance of Americas indigenous art form jazz, and related styles of music from around the world. Founded in 1997, the Jazzschool is located in the historic Kress Building on the northwest corner of Shattuck Avenue and Addison street situated in the heart of the Downtown Berkeley Arts District. Integrating a number of unique resources complementary to jazz study and performance, the Jazzschool resides in a diverse and thriving arts community with the Freight and Salvage Coffeehouse, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Aurora Theater, Berkeley Rep School of Theatre, East Bay Media Center and the Art & Music Room in the Berkeley Public Library. Hailed as one of the most comprehensive schools for jazz in the country, the Jazzschool offers instrumentalists and vocalists of all ages and levels a broad spectrum of performance and lecture classes, short-term workshops and private instruction through two distinct educational programs: the Jazzschool Community Music School, encompassing the Adult Music Program and the Young Musicians Program, and the Jazzschool Institute, a post-secondary degree program offering a B.Mus in Jazz Studies. Classes are designed for the professional musician, the serious student and the jazz aficionado seeking personal enrichment. Jazzschool Books and Records serves as a resource for first-rate reading and listening materials and provides students, educators, and the public with supplemental educational materials, out-of-the-ordinary books, recordings, videos and music-related accessories. The Jazzcaffnd The Jazz Image (a photography gallery featuring works by Lee Tanner) contribute to an intimate setting for faculty and student performances (see concert schedule, p. 40. The Jazzcafflso serves as a gathering place for musicians and their families and friends to exchange ideas, listen to great music and enjoy a bite to eat. The Jazzschool is easily accessible by public transportation. The downtown Berkeley BART station at Center Street is located less than half a block from the Jazzschools front door and AC Transit bus stops are nearby. In addition to metered street parking and passenger loading zones, there is a public parking garage less than a block away.

event.description:
Three Northern California reggae bands share the stage in Aloha Night, a mini-music festival. No, they don’t play Hawaiian music, but two of the groups – Mango Kingz and One A-Chord – have big followings in Hawaii and both have popular singles on the radio this month in the 50th state. Along with Native Elements, they bring highly melodic and conscious reggae dance music and turn Ashkenaz into a tropical paradise.

Native Elements is one of the largest (with full horn section) and hardest-working groups on the local reggae scene, having played to dancing throngs from San Francisco’s Reggae in the Park to Humboldt County’s Reggae on the River, with their music featured in the film “Debut.” They performed at last February’s Ashkenaz Bob Marley Birthday Celebration. The Bay Area’s cultural and musical diversity has fueled the band’s creative flow from its start nearly 20 years ago, with musicians who had grown up together since elementary school, playing in garage bands and skateboarding through Daly City and South San Francisco. After explorations with rock, funk, blues, and R&B, Native Elements set its repertoire firmly in the roots-reggae tradition, combining conscious, uplifting lyrics with an instrumental fabric that includes improvised solos, lovers rock, roots, and dancehall wrapped cozily in what the band calls its bright “frisco-pino” treatment. Along with the latest band originals, shows include classic reggae by Bob Marley and other Jamaican greats. The dozen members combine their colorful influences to deliver positive, vibrant music that speaks from the heart.

www.native-elements.com

The Bay Area’s Mango Kingz create an island reggae sound that spans generations. The band brings a little bit of aloha to the mainland. The group’s first single, “You Got Me,” is a favorite of Hawaiian radio, with a full album due early next year.

www.mangokingz.com

One A-Chord is Monterey’s premier “island reggae” band, busily spreading its fusion of Polynesian reggae vibe and island-style sounds, rocking the cities of Northern California. The group has performed at some of Northern California’s largest reggae events including twice at the Monterey Reggae Fest. One A-Chord lifts spirits and raises the dance energy with its blend of soulful R&B and rootsy reggae sound.

www.onea-chord.com

event.description:
Park and trail organizations around the Bay Area want to make it easier for people to visit their parks and trails. Web-based maps, trip-planning APIs, mobile-optimized websites and mobile applications are tools that can be used for this purpose. The Bay Area Open Space Council, with support from Kaiser Permanente, is facilitating a set of regional meetings to create a coordinated plan for “maps and apps.” One size will most likely not fit all but there is a lot we can do to share information, leverage resources and partner to reach our common goals. 

Our next meeting will be held on December 12, 2012 from 9am-12pm at the Brower Center in Berkeley.

The goals will be to: 1) learn more about the technology solutions available; and 2) further refine and prioritize projects to collaborate on.

An agenda will be distributed in advance to those who register.

organizer.description: The Bay Area Open Space Council is a collaborative of member organizations actively involved in permanently protecting and stewarding important parks, trails and agricultural lands in the ten-county San Francisco Bay Area.

Awesome Food, Candle Lighting, Open Mic, Gift Exchange

 

SCHEDULE

As with every Urban Adamah event, please bring a canned good or make a $2 donation to our food bank when you arrive.

event.description: Sarchasm is a pop-punk band from the Easy Bay that draws influence from several different areas: the fast-paced angst-core music of the Berkeley punk scene, the pop simplicity of The Beatles, and the youthful spirit of teenagers. Crafting heartfelt songs that draw influence from the rich leftism of the Bay Area, their peers, and the world around them, Sarchasm tackles subjects such as the injustice of war and police brutality ("Apathy", "Point Blank Range"), friendship ("Your Rock", "Trains"), and social commentary ("The Agony of my Heart", "Supersize Me"). Capturing inspiration from the likes of Green Day, Rancid, Streetlight Manifesto, and Nirvana, Sarchasm has created a unique sound that boasts of pop roots and punk ideals, with a little bit of ska sprinkled in for a good measure - music that both parents and children alike can get up and dance to. Also Featuring! Nothing to Lose, Girl Genius, & Don't Flirt With Puppykillers. All Ages Welcome!

event.description:
House favorites the Caribbean Allstars present a night of calypso festivities for the holidays, with special guest singers from the islands. The extravaganza includes up-and-coming calypso singers Tony L from Trinidad and Nicolas Ki from the Virgin Islands.

The Caribbean Allstars are pioneers in the Bay Area reggae scene and longtime regulars at Ashkenaz. The ensemble, whose geographical roots range from Jamaica and South America to West Africa and the United States, began joining together their musical forces and international backgrounds during the early 1970s. Out of such predecessors as Obeah and the Sons of Creation, the Caribbean Allstars were formed and became the founding fathers of Bay Area roots reggae.

The Caribbean Allstars not only play Jamaican reggae with a traditional electric bass-drums-guitars-keyboards lineup, but also add steel drums to bring in South Caribbean calypso and soca styles of Trinidad and Tobago, producing rhythms that drive listeners to the dance floor. Over the years the band has performed with an array of talent sitting in, including Taj Mahal, Narada Michael Walden and Carlos Santana. Santana played on their second album and introduced them as “my favorite band” at the 1987 Bay Area Music Awards (Bammies).

www.thecaribbeanallstars.com

event.description: Bassist has already built an impressive resume as a sideman, having performed with Ravi Coltrane, Josh Roseman and Julian Pollack, among many others. Now Garabedian leads his own ensemble for the first time on the west coast. A sextet with a rollicking horn section that draws from Dixieland and Afrobeat, Big Butter and The Egg Men perform Garabedian’s originals, inspired by everything from Malian wassoulou music and Bach to Jamiroquai. Featuring Pat Carroll, alto sax; Hitomi Oba, tenor sax; Kyle Wilson, tenor sax; Raffi Garabedian, tenor sax; and Evan Hughes, drums. "Noah is a positively organic bass player, an incredible artist..." - David Wiegand, The San Francisco Chronicle

event.description:
This 3-part workshop series is designed for singers interested in developing the vocal consistency necessary to effortlessly sing and interpret songs. Students are encouraged to take all three workshops to absorb the techniques in these exciting and interactive classes.

Week One: ConnectedVoice Technique ConnectedVoice technique is a fresh way of developing connected and consistent sound from low to high range, with a choice of dynamics and colors. This is accomplished by working through vocal transitions with exercises designed to connect the speaking and singing voice, and to connect voice development with ear training. Linguistic tools are given to solve specific technical issues, and scale and chordpatterns are provided that are specially tailored to developing jazz singers. In this workshop, students explore the principles and the exercises of this technique and apply it to songs. Please bring in problem songs!

Week Two: More ConnectedVoice Students review the exercises and techniques of ConnectedVoice, and then explore how the choice of vowel shapes can help apply the technique to songs. Finally, students work on application of the technique to songs. Please bring in problem songs!

Week Three: Points of Departure In order to interpret vocal jazz repertoire with freedom and musicality, the jazz singer needs to have certain grounding skills:

• a good sense of rhythm and groove • a basic knowledge of chords: how they sound and how they move • a great sense of pitch In this workshop, students focus on physicalizing time and groove. The class explores 7th chords — how to sing them, and how to hear and follow them as they move in order to interpret jazz repertoire in relation to the chord progression. Finally, students are introduced to applied ear training exercises.  $150/series or $75 per session

organizer.description: The Jazzschool is an innovative music school dedicated to the study and performance of Americas indigenous art form jazz, and related styles of music from around the world. Founded in 1997, the Jazzschool is located in the historic Kress Building on the northwest corner of Shattuck Avenue and Addison street situated in the heart of the Downtown Berkeley Arts District. Integrating a number of unique resources complementary to jazz study and performance, the Jazzschool resides in a diverse and thriving arts community with the Freight and Salvage Coffeehouse, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Aurora Theater, Berkeley Rep School of Theatre, East Bay Media Center and the Art & Music Room in the Berkeley Public Library. Hailed as one of the most comprehensive schools for jazz in the country, the Jazzschool offers instrumentalists and vocalists of all ages and levels a broad spectrum of performance and lecture classes, short-term workshops and private instruction through two distinct educational programs: the Jazzschool Community Music School, encompassing the Adult Music Program and the Young Musicians Program, and the Jazzschool Institute, a post-secondary degree program offering a B.Mus in Jazz Studies. Classes are designed for the professional musician, the serious student and the jazz aficionado seeking personal enrichment. Jazzschool Books and Records serves as a resource for first-rate reading and listening materials and provides students, educators, and the public with supplemental educational materials, out-of-the-ordinary books, recordings, videos and music-related accessories. The Jazzcaffnd The Jazz Image (a photography gallery featuring works by Lee Tanner) contribute to an intimate setting for faculty and student performances (see concert schedule, p. 40. The Jazzcafflso serves as a gathering place for musicians and their families and friends to exchange ideas, listen to great music and enjoy a bite to eat. The Jazzschool is easily accessible by public transportation. The downtown Berkeley BART station at Center Street is located less than half a block from the Jazzschools front door and AC Transit bus stops are nearby. In addition to metered street parking and passenger loading zones, there is a public parking garage less than a block away.

event.title: ConnectedVoice 3-Part Workshops with Sandy Cressman

event.description: Rhythm Changes — Probably the second most common set of chord changes in jazz, “I’ve Got Rhythm” and its variants have been recorded thousands of times and by just about every jazz player. Alternate melodies include Salt Peanuts, Anthropology / Thriving on a Riff, Oleo, The Flintstones, Lemon Drop, Lester Leaps In, Shaw Nuff, and hundreds more. Learn how to get inside of these changes and become more comfortable improvising, trading, and having musical conversations over Rhythm Changes. January 27, 2013 Noon – 3 pm $50 advance purchase/$65 day of the workshop Stephen Saxon is a singer and trumpet player who has performed jazz, classical, klezmer, and cantorial music over a professional career that began in the 1970s. He has performed and/or recorded with Chet Baker, Michael Brecker, Chanticleer, Richie Cole, David Grisman, Dave Gruisin, Kitka, Bill Henderson, KlezX, Abbey Lincoln (Aminata Moseka), Bobby McFerrin, Mark Murphy, Pacific Mozart Ensemble, Ed Reed, Martha Schlamme, Gunther Schuller, Michael Tilson Thomas, Craig Taubman, Mal Waldron, Andy Williams, John Williams, and Frank Zappa, among others.

event.title: Vocal Improvisation with Stephen Saxon - Rhythm Changes

event.description: Song Forms and the ii-V-I Progression— If it’s not blues and it’s not Rhythm Changes, chances are the song is going to be based on some combination of ii-V-I chord progressions. Learn to recognize these by sight and by ear, and pick up melodic ideas that work to get you from here to there. A variety of songs will be used for this hands-on workshop. You’ve heard the term, but do you really understand the theory behind the ii-V-I? Can you recognize it when you hear it? By the end of this workshop you will be able to say yes to both of those questions, and you’ll be able to get through ii-V-I progressions comfortably while expressing yourself through improvised melodies. April 14, 2013 Noon – 3 pm $50 advance purchase/$65 day of the workshop Stephen Saxon is a singer and trumpet player who has performed jazz, classical, klezmer, and cantorial music over a professional career that began in the 1970s. He has performed and/or recorded with Chet Baker, Michael Brecker, Chanticleer, Richie Cole, David Grisman, Dave Gruisin, Kitka, Bill Henderson, KlezX, Abbey Lincoln (Aminata Moseka), Bobby McFerrin, Mark Murphy, Pacific Mozart Ensemble, Ed Reed, Martha Schlamme, Gunther Schuller, Michael Tilson Thomas, Craig Taubman, Mal Waldron, Andy Williams, John Williams, and Frank Zappa, among others.

event.title: Vocal Improvisation - Stephen Saxon - Song Forms and the ii-V-I Progression

event.description: Acting for Singers There are many talented vocalists out there, but when it comes down to it not many are able to reach into their arsenal of skills and pull out a good act. When you step on stage you are an actor. You portray the song and its emotions and you tell a story. In this workshop you will learn the fundamentals of stage acting, and how to bring out your inner actor and show the audience that you are capable of another level of performance. Wear comfortable clothes and bring one chart in your key. February 17, 2013 Noon – 3 pm $50 advance purchase/$65 day of the workshop

event.title: Acting for Singers with Lisa Lindsley

event.description: Storytelling and the Standards Learn how to transition from one song to the next through stories and stage banter. Having a good flow keeps your audience engaged. A small story, a short joke or witty repartee during your performance can make all the difference to draw your audience in. Learn how to craft a story that will then go smoothly into your next song. We will also work on improving comfort level on-stage and getting rid of those butterflies that can plague us when we have to speak in front of an audience. Wear comfortable clothes and bring two charts in your key. April 21, 2013 Noon – 3 pm $50 advance purchase/$65 day of the workshop

event.title: Storytelling and the Standards with Lisa Lindsley

event.description:
The Music of Rodgers and Hart Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart composed dozens of songs beloved by jazz singers and instrumentalists. Some famous titles include “Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered,” “The Lady is a Tramp,” “Where or When,” “Blue Moon,” and “I Could Write a Book.” In this workshop, singers explore the music of these two great musicians. Students also explore how jazz greats have interpreted these songs and made them their own.

February 10, 17, and 24, 2013 Noon – 3 pm $220 advance purchase/$235 day of the workshop (for 3-part workshop)

Instructor provides 10 charts and practice tracks for each workshop series. Class time is spent learning the songs and developing new arrangements. In the 3rd meeting of each series, students work with an accompanist. Maximum enrollment: 8

event.title: Composer Workshop Series with Maye Cavallaro -The Music of Rodgers and Hart

event.description: Over the Rainbow: The Music of Harold Arlen Harold Arlen is known for his bluesy and harmonically sophisticated tunes. He paired with the best lyricists of his day including Ted Koehler (with whom he wrote “Let’s Fall in Love,” and “Stormy Weather,”) and with E.Y. “Yip” Harburg (with whom he wrote the music for The Wizard of Oz.) In this workshop, singers explore the music of Arlen including well-known tunes and some not so wellknown. Students also listen to how jazz greats have interpreted these songs to get ideas for their own arrangements. May 19, 26 and June 2, 2013 Noon – 3 pm $220 advance purchase/$235 day of the workshop (for each 3-part workshop) Instructor provides 10 charts and practice tracks for each workshop series. Class time is spent learning the songs and developing new arrangements. In the 3rd meeting of each series, students work with an accompanist. Maximum enrollment: 8

event.title: Composer Workshop Series with Maye Cavallaro -The Music of Harold Arlen

event.description: Influence and Inspiration: Behind the Scenes of a Tribute to Bobby Hutcherson In this hands-on, experiential workshop, vibraphonist and composer Chris Dingman demonstrates how his playing and compositions are influenced by jazz legend Bobby Hutcherson, through a short performance and multimedia presentation.  Students are then invited to participate in group exercises, discussion, and performance, all focused on tapping in to creative inspiration through the study of the music that influences us the most.  Students will gain insight into the process of self-discovery through their love of the music of the masters, and will take away specific exercises and methods to use in daily practice. Saturday December 15, 3:15 - 4:45 pm $30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop Chris Dingman Hailed by the New York Times as a "dazzling" soloist and composer with a "fondness for airtight logic and burnished lyricism," Chris Dingman is one of the most sought-after vibraphonists of his generation. Schooled in the jazz tradition, yet influenced by a wide range of music and experience, Dingman draws inspiration and meaning from a diverse set of musical sources, uniting them in a progressive approach that has earned him praise for his "poignant work" (David Sprague, Variety), his "adaptive humility" (Nate Chinen, NY Times), and as "downright hypnotic" (John Barron, All About Jazz). He has performed and studied with many of the world's greatest jazz musicians, including Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter, Benny Golson, Jimmy Heath, and many others. Now based in Brooklyn, NY, he is currently working with many of the leading lights on the jazz and creative music scene, both as a sideman and as a leader. His debut album, Waking Dreams, has been called "gorgeous" (Time Out NY), "brilliant" (All About Jazz), and "deeply lyrical" (NY Times). Stereophile calls it "a very big, pleasant surprise" and the Los Angeles Times commends: "rich and full of unexpected twists but never less than approachable, Waking Dreams casts an atmospheric spell true to its name." Presented in collaboration with SFJAZZ.

organizer.description: The Jazzschool is an innovative music school dedicated to the study and performance of Americas indigenous art form jazz, and related styles of music from around the world. Founded in 1997, the Jazzschool is located in the historic Kress Building on the northwest corner of Shattuck Avenue and Addison street situated in the heart of the Downtown Berkeley Arts District. Integrating a number of unique resources complementary to jazz study and performance, the Jazzschool resides in a diverse and thriving arts community with the Freight and Salvage Coffeehouse, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Aurora Theater, Berkeley Rep School of Theatre, East Bay Media Center and the Art & Music Room in the Berkeley Public Library. Hailed as one of the most comprehensive schools for jazz in the country, the Jazzschool offers instrumentalists and vocalists of all ages and levels a broad spectrum of performance and lecture classes, short-term workshops and private instruction through two distinct educational programs: the Jazzschool Community Music School, encompassing the Adult Music Program and the Young Musicians Program, and the Jazzschool Institute, a post-secondary degree program offering a B.Mus in Jazz Studies. Classes are designed for the professional musician, the serious student and the jazz aficionado seeking personal enrichment. Jazzschool Books and Records serves as a resource for first-rate reading and listening materials and provides students, educators, and the public with supplemental educational materials, out-of-the-ordinary books, recordings, videos and music-related accessories. The Jazzcaffnd The Jazz Image (a photography gallery featuring works by Lee Tanner) contribute to an intimate setting for faculty and student performances (see concert schedule, p. 40. The Jazzcafflso serves as a gathering place for musicians and their families and friends to exchange ideas, listen to great music and enjoy a bite to eat. The Jazzschool is easily accessible by public transportation. The downtown Berkeley BART station at Center Street is located less than half a block from the Jazzschools front door and AC Transit bus stops are nearby. In addition to metered street parking and passenger loading zones, there is a public parking garage less than a block away.

event.title: Chris Dingman Improvisation Workshop

event.description: The slow songs of the jazz repertoire may be less technically demanding than their faster counterparts, but they require special skills and arguably greater artistry to play credibly. In this workshop we tackle those skills head on, focusing on phrasing and feel, and outline practical avenues for improving your artistry. We also explore rubato, cadenzas and double-time feel as time allows. Prerequisites: facility on a melodic instrument or vocals, improvisational experience, and knowledge of basic jazz harmony. Bring your instrument (recommended). Sunday Dec. 9, 11 am - 1:30 pm $40 advance purchase/$55 day of the workshop Anton Schwartz

event.title: Developing Your Ballad Skills

event.description: The final moments of a song are crucial to the lasting impression it leaves. This workshop for both rhythm section players and soloists addresses all the practical elements of pulling it off in style. Topics include: ritards, taking harmonic cues, playing over single and multiple fermatas, arranged endings, endings on the fly, nonverbal band communication. Bring your instruments, as there will be ample playing and critique! Prerequisites: Experience performing songs and improvising. Sunday Dec. 9, 1:45 - 4:15pm $40 advance purchase/$55 day of the workshop Anton Schwartz

event.title: Happy Endings - The Art of Ending a Tune

event.description: Henry Moser Group has been tearing up the Bay Area funk, jazz and rock scenes, getting audiences on their feet and dancing while gaining notice for singer/songwriter Henry Moser's unique and catchy blend of pop, folk melodies and jazz harmony. The dynamic quartet balances softer, introspective sections with energetic, grooving improvisation. For this special Jazzschool performance, Henry Moser Group debuts songs from the their debut album, out this spring on Jazzschool Records. Featuring Henry Moser, guitar and vocals; Chris Sullivan, alto sax; Tommy O’Mahony, bass; and Nick De Ryss, drums.

event.title: Tommy O’Mahony

event.description: A high-energy musical collaboration of Bay Area natives Jon Hatamiya (trombone), Albert Baliwas (sax), Colin McDaniel (drums), Kevin Bernstein (piano) and John Snow (bass). Before the age of 21, these five musicians have already compiled an impressive list of performance credits, including appearances with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, the Taylor Eigsti Trio, Dianne Reeves, Seamus Blake, Steve Wilson, and Ambrose Akinmusire, and have performed at venues such as the Monterey Jazz Festival, Yoshi’s Oakland and SF, the Jazz Standard, Staples Center, and the Hollywood Bowl. Drawing from influences in rock, R&B, funk, electronic music, and contemporary classical music, Nice Young Men present a highly original set of music in the traditional context of a jazz quintet.

event.description: Four Berkeley High Jazz alumni return from their studies around the country to play a unique and exciting show filled with original compositions, jazz standards, and more. Featuring Grant Milliken, vibraphone; Nick Lamb, piano; Erik Shiboski, bass; and Lev Facher, drums.

event.title: The Homecoming Collective: Erik Shiboski, Grant Milliken, Lev Facher, and Nick Lamb

event.description: Trombonist Nick Grinder returns to the Bay Area fresh off his first year of living in New York City, bringing two sets of new, original music with him. Nick grew up in Novato, CA, and is performing with close friends and fellow New York transplants Jill Ryan (sax) and Jordan Carrington (piano), as well as former Novatoan and East Coaster, drummer Nick De Ryss. Also featuring Nick Grinder, trombone; and Tommy O’Mahony, bass.

organizer.description: The Jazzschool is an innovative music school dedicated to the study and performance of Americas indigenous art form jazz, and related styles of music from around the world. Founded in 1997, the Jazzschool is located in the historic Kress Building on the northwest corner of Shattuck Avenue and Addison street situated in the heart of the Downtown Berkeley Arts District. Integrating a number of unique resources complementary to jazz study and performance, the Jazzschool resides in a diverse and thriving arts community with the Freight and Salvage Coffeehouse, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Aurora Theater, Berkeley Rep School of Theatre, East Bay Media Center and the Art & Music Room in the Berkeley Public Library. Hailed as one of the most comprehensive schools for jazz in the country, the Jazzschool offers instrumentalists and vocalists of all ages and levels a broad spectrum of performance and lecture classes, short-term workshops and private instruction through two distinct educational programs: the Jazzschool Community Music School, encompassing the Adult Music Program and the Young Musicians Program, and the Jazzschool Institute, a post-secondary degree program offering a B.Mus in Jazz Studies. Classes are designed for the professional musician, the serious student and the jazz aficionado seeking personal enrichment. Jazzschool Books and Records serves as a resource for first-rate reading and listening materials and provides students, educators, and the public with supplemental educational materials, out-of-the-ordinary books, recordings, videos and music-related accessories. The Jazzcaffnd The Jazz Image (a photography gallery featuring works by Lee Tanner) contribute to an intimate setting for faculty and student performances (see concert schedule, p. 40. The Jazzcafflso serves as a gathering place for musicians and their families and friends to exchange ideas, listen to great music and enjoy a bite to eat. The Jazzschool is easily accessible by public transportation. The downtown Berkeley BART station at Center Street is located less than half a block from the Jazzschools front door and AC Transit bus stops are nearby. In addition to metered street parking and passenger loading zones, there is a public parking garage less than a block away.

event.title: Nick Grinder's New-Old Quintet

event.description: This workshop focuses on various aspects of Gypsy guitar in the tradition of Django Reinhardt. Topics include rhythm, picking, scales, arpeggios, chords, soloing, and more. One-on-one evaluation is available to all attendees, with a directed jam at the conclusion of the workshop (time permitting!). Bring your instrument, recording device (and/or paper and pencil) and questions! Instructor Paul Mehling is the leader of the Hot Club of San Francisco www.hcsf.com $30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop

event.title: Paul Mehling - Unlocking the Secrets of Gypsy Jazz Guitar

event.description: Returning with his popular workshop for musicians and singers of all levels, Mehling demonstrates a range of practice techniques making creative use of the metronome. Improve your productivity and increase your musicianship! Open to all. Instructor Paul Mehling is the leader of the Hot Club of San Francisco www.hcsf.com $30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop

event.title: Paul Mehling - The Metronome is Your Friend

event.description: Jazzschool Institute faculty Arjun Verma presents a concert of North Indian classical music on sitar, accompanied by Nikhil Pandya on tabla. North Indian classical music combines traditional melodies and rhythms with dynamic improvisation and interaction between musicians, covering the musical spectrum from deeply contemplative to exhilarating. Verma is a student of Ali Akbar Khan and has performed around the world, including performances at the United Nations in Geneva and Prague Castle in the Czech Republic. Verma and Pandya are on the faculty of the Ali Akbar College of Music.

event.title: Arjun Verma and Nikhil Pandya: Classical Sitar and Tabla Performance

event.description: Pianist Dahveed Behroozi, bassist Thomas Morgan and drummer Tim Bulkley have developed a symbiotic musical relationship that comes from playing together on and off for many years. Separately, the three are involved in a wealth of musical projects. As a trio, they combine their wide-ranging interests for an always adventurous evening of originals and new takes on standards from the Great American Songbook.

event.title: Dhaveed Behroozi Trio

event.description: French ‘soul-jazz’ organist Michel Bénébig is a master on the Hammond B3, in the tradition of great jazz and blues organists Jack McDuff, Jimmy McGriff and Jimmy Smith. Performing with vocalist SHEM, Bénébig presents originals alongside classic jazz and blues.

event.title: Michel Bénébig

event.description: Grupo Falso Baiano members Zack Pitt-Smith (reeds), Brian Moran (7 string guitar/mandolin/cavaquinho), and Ami Molinelli (pandeiro/percussion) discuss choro essentials for those new to the genre, their experiences playing in Brazil and the US, as well as strategies for arranging classic choros, different grooves and articulations, the roles of the different instruments, playing in choro jam sessions (rodas) and more. This workshop is participatory, so bring your instruments! Grupo Falso Baiano was created by Pitt-Smith, Moran and Molinelli in 2003 to explore modern and old school choro. They have played throughout CA at clubs and in festivals over the years. Their 2008 release Viajando Choro e Jazz was produced by Michael Spiro, and featured special guests Jovino Santos Neto, Mike Marshall, Jorge Alabe among others. Their second CD Simplicidade: Live at Yoshi’s was released in August of 2011. www.grupofalsobaiano.com for more info. $30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop

event.title: Choro Workshop with Grupo Falso Baiano

event.description: Come meet the Cuban tres and get a taste of the minor percussion instruments associated with Afro-Cuban rhythms. The Cuban tres is a guitar-like instrument with three double strings (six in all). It plays a key role in the Cuban “son,” the heartbeat of salsa. The minor percussion instruments include the maracas, guiro (gourd scraper) and clave sticks. Learn how these instruments weave together to create the rich polyrhythms of Afro-Cuban music. This workshop includes an explanation and hands-on demonstration of the Cuban tres, and a demonstration of the techniques used in playing claves, maracas and guiro. Time permitting: a descarga (jam session) with all of the instruments. Open to all musicians. Heriberto “Tito” Gonzalez, “El Tresero mayor,” arrived in the San Francisco Bay Area in the summer of 2000. His music is typical and primarily “El Son,” as exemplified by the Buena Vista Social Club. Tito studied with Tres master Papi Oviedo of the Buena Vista Social Club and then with the greatest guitarist in Cuba, Octavio Sanchez Cotán. He has played with such famous Cuban groups as Conjunto Estrellas de Chocolate, Aribu Quartet and Chapotin y sus estrellas, all from Havana, Cuba. $30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop

event.title: Tito Gonzalez - Cuban Music Workshop - The Tres & Minor Percussion

event.description: An in-demand sideman and leader of his own acclaimed groups, pianist Erik Deutsch comes to the Jazzschool in support of his new album “Demonio Teclado,” a psychedelic blend of retro soul-jazz and rock. Recorded live to 1/4-tape in Erik's building in Williamsburg, the songs are a fun, listenable blend of groove, sonic exploration, and modern jazz composition. Also featuring Jon Gray, trumpet/vocals; Jeff Hill, bass; and Tony Mason, drums. Having first come to prominence as a member of the funk-jazz collective Fat Mama, Erik Deutsch has taken his talents across the country to play with some of the finest musicians available. Currently living in Brooklyn, NY, Erik splits his time between his own band and backing up artists such as Norah Jones, Rosanne Cash, Alice Smith, Ellery Eskelin, Ben Allison, Steven Bernstein, and Theo Bleckmann.  Deutsch holds the distinction of being the only keyboardist to tour regularly with 7-string guitar master Charlie Hunter, and is spent much of 2012 on the road with Shooter Jennings in support of their new album Family Man (on which he is prominently featured). "Demonio Teclado...suggests a postmillennial update of the 1970s crossover paragons like Eddie Harris and George Duke" -- Nate Chinen, NY Times

event.description: Raul Perales (bass), Maya Kronfeld (piano) and Rafa Postel (trumpet) have played together in various settings for many years. Now they come together as a trio to showcase their original compositions and arrangements. Steeped in jazz, soul, and Afro-Latino music, this rich and soulful music is a feast for the ears. www.raulperalesmusic.com

event.title: Raul Perales Quartet

event.description: The Horizon Trio is a collaborative project featuring three acclaimed performers/educators: guitarist Steven Kirby, bassist Ed Lucie and drummer Mike Connors. From melodic ballads to burning uptempo excursions, highly arranged compositions to free improvisation, this is a versatile and adventurous trio with a penchant for melodicism and lyrical expression. Steven Kirby is a professor at Berklee College of Music and has released two critically acclaimed CDs as a leader on Challenge Records: “North Light” and “Point Of Balance.” He has performed at jazz festivals throughout North America and Europe, and is a contributor to Guitar Player Magazine and True Fire. "Kirby plays and writes from inside the music, putting melody and feeling first."– Bob Blumenthal, Boston Globe Ed Lucie is a professor a Berklee College of Music. He has performed around the world, with artists such as Buddy Rich, Stevie Wonder and Warren Haynes, and is a contributor to Bass Player Magazine. Mike Connors is a professor at Clark Univesity and Rivers School. He has performed with Combustible Edison, Bryan Ferry, among others.

event.title: The Horizons Trio

event.description:
Berklee College of Music faculty member Ed Lucie explains and demonstrates the use of chord tones in creating interesting and supportive bass lines in many styles. The use of chord tones to develop melodic improvisation is also addressed.
Please bring your bass! There will be opportunity for questions and answers as well as a chance to try the concepts. Open to all!
Ed Lucie received his BM from Berklee College of Music and his MM from the New England Conservatory. He has performed with Buddy Rich, Stevie Wonder, Warren Haynes and Gov’t Mule and Leo Nocentelli. He is also a contributor to Bass Player Magazine.

event.title: Bass Workshop: creating strong bass lines and improvising effective solos

event.description:
New England-based drummer Mike Connors offers a jazz drum set workshop open to drummers of all levels.
A wide range of topics are covered including:
-How to practice -Exercises for increasing hand technique -Creative use of rudiments -How to practice using a metronome -Developing a vocabulary for jazz comping -Basic brush patterns -Solo construction and development inside and outside form -Grooves everyone should know -Introduction to odd meters -Applying your existing 4/4 vocabulary to odd meters
Mike Connors has toured internationally for the past twenty years with a variety of jazz and pop artists and has performed on over 50 albums and several movie sound tracks. He is currently on Faculty at Clark University and the Rivers Conservatory.
$30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop

event.title: Mike Connors - Jazz Drum Set Workshop

event.description: This workshop focuses on gaining fluency while improvising over changes by learning to write and improvise musically interesting and effective constant 8th note solos. Want to be able to jazz up your blues playing? Create interesting new sounds over a tired vamp? Flow through fast moving changes in a free and creative way? Learning to create effective melodic flow while still “describing" the harmonic underpinnings of a tune, as well as being able to convincingly superimpose reharmonization ideas for that tune, is a prerequisite for most styles of music which involve improvising over harmony. Though effective solos will ultimately contain rhythmic variety, improvisors need to develop harmonic fluency so that they can "make" the changes in an interesting and creative way. One tried and true way to get that skill is to work on constant 8th note exercises which lead to creating non-mechanical sounding, musically effective, fluent passages. Once the ability to create interest with a long flow of well chosen notes is acquired, the improviser can fairly easily learn to incorporate rhythmic variety and rhythmic development by paring things down, while still retaining the solid and creative relationship with the harmony. Session participants will be given a series of guidelines (derived from insight gained from  transcriptions of great solos), examples of effective constant 8th note material applied to common sets of chord changes and the opportunity to try out the concepts in the workshop by writing and playing themselves. The material in this workshop is applicable to all improvising instrumentalists and vocalists. An intermediate level of theory knowledge, including the ability to spell chords, along with the ability to read music on your instrument, and some experience with improvising over changing harmony are suggested prerequisites. Please bring your instrument/voice! $30 advance purchase/$45 day of the workshop

event.title: Steven Kirby -Learn to Make the Changes by Going With the (8th note) Flow

event.description:
In this workshop, Stephanie Nakasian demonstrates specific elements of style, phrasing and improvisation derived from the study of some of the most important and influential jazz vocalists including Sarah Vaughan, Billie Holiday, Peggy Lee, and others in order to help singers acquire good, pure 'ingredients' of authentic jazz to mix with their own personal, contemporary interpretations of jazz singing.
$50 advance purchase/$65 day of the workshop

The Jazzcafflso serves as a gathering place for musicians and their families and friends to exchange ideas, listen to great music and enjoy a bite to eat. The Jazzschool is easily accessible by public transportation. The downtown Berkeley BART station at Center Street is located less than half a block from the Jazzschools front door and AC Transit bus stops are nearby. In addition to metered street parking and passenger loading zones, there is a public parking garage less than a block away.

event.title: Stephanie Nakasian - Bringing Singers from the Past to the Present

event.description: A first-class vocal jazz musician, Stephanie Crawford’s rich, expressive voice is deepened by a lifetime of gigs and the ghosts of nightclubs past. Her consummate skill as a storyteller, arranger, and improviser has brought her worldwide recognition -- she is the winner of the 1993 Django D'Or “Best Jazz Vocalist” and 2009 East Bay Express “Best Singer” awards.

event.title: Vocal Jam Session

event.description: Designed for players accustomed to using a single scale for each song they improvise over, this interactive workshop introduces participants to the rich experience of improvising over changing harmony. The leap from jamming over a chord or a blues scale to playing meaningfully over moving chords can be overwhelming; this workshop breaks it down through progressive exercises that allow students to hear and feel the changes of harmony, paving the way for students to play over chord changes as a natural expression of emotion rather than an intellectual exercise. Participants learn to improvise over a 12-bar blues like a jazz musician, bringing out the unique sound of each part of the blues form, rather than treating it all as an undifferentiated whole. Prerequisites: knowledge of major and minor scales and facility on a melodic instrument. Bring your instrument. There will be a 30-minute lunch break. $75 advance purchase/$90 day of the workshop 11am - 4pm Anton Schwartz

event.title: Beyond The Blues Scale - Schwartz

event.description: Learn how to get inside of and become more comfortable improvising, trading, and having musical conversations over Rhythm Changes, one of the most common chord progressions in jazz. STEPHEN SAXON $50 Stephen Saxon is a singer and trumpet player who has performed jazz, classical, klezmer, and cantorial music over a professional career that began in the 1970s. He has performed and/or recorded with Chet Baker, Michael Brecker, Chanticleer, Richie Cole, David Grisman, Dave Gruisin, Kitka, Bill Henderson, KlezX, Abbey Lincoln (Aminata Moseka), Bobby McFerrin, Mark Murphy, Pacific Mozart Ensemble, Ed Reed, Martha Schlamme, Gunther Schuller, Michael Tilson Thomas, Craig Taubman, Mal Waldron, Andy Williams, John Williams, and Frank Zappa, among others.

event.title: Vocal Improvisation — Rhythm Changes

event.description:
Are you ready to create an authentic vision for your new year?

Do you love expressing yourself through art and/or collage?

Would you like to learn easy tips to breakthrough old patterns?

As the new year approaches us often thoughts of new year's goals,
hopes, aspirations, dreams, plans begin percolating in our minds.
As this year ends, we think back to our joys, triumphs, challenges,
let-downs, and transitions. How can we nurture those dreams,
aspirations, goals, and vision? How can we get clear on what the
vision is in the first place? Over the years in my own life and in
working with friends and clients, I've found a useful tool in getting
clarity in times of transition: The Vision Board.

We will be creating collages on poster boards exploring,
representing and activating our unique visions for 2013, gently
supported, guided, and nurtured by Viviana Lahrs.


You will enjoy two dynamic and experiential discussions to prepare
and support your visioning 2013. All materials and supplies, tea,
snacks, will be provided!




What is Included:
~ Tea ceremony & Opening Circle (To set the inner body intentions for the workshop)
~ Two dynamic enrichment classes to support your vision (By Stacy Vatja & Tahil Gesyuk)
~ All materials (Poster boards, magazines, glue, odds and ends, art supply, etc.)
~ Delicious Healthy Snacks to fuel or creations (Organic, Vegetarian, and Vegan options)
~ Ambient Music (you may bring your own headphones/mp3 player)
~ Sharing and Closing Community Circle

Cost: $129, early bird (Available until 12/1/12, $144 there-after.)
(Limited work-trade and scholarships available, please inquire.)

Date: Jan. 5th, 2013
Time: 2:00-7:00pm
Location: Sticky Art Lab! 1682 University Ave, Berkeley, CA 94703
http://stickyartlab.comContact:  Viviana at 510-910-3482 or viviana@intimacyforumtraining.com


The afternoon is composed of  two engaging classes to prepare our
body, mind, and spirit and ends with the hands on vision board
creation time:

Clearing of Energy, "Catching Spirit", & Group Healing,
with Stacy Vatja:
What if you could “catch” Spirit’s idea of your life – what and where
you should put your energy into – as you step into the New Year?

Activating the Map: "Breaking the Habits" for Visioning in Your
Life & Relationships, with Tahil Gesyuk:
An interactive talk about how to own your challenges and use them
as stepping stones to use them for your vision to bloom.

Discovering the Vision: Creating Your Compass,
with Viviana Lahrs:
A gently guided workshop to create your own vision board for 2013,
group share, and activation.

Schedule:
1:45-2:15 Meet and Greet with Tea Service (Please arrive early to park and enjoy the tea)
2:15-2:30 Intro by Viviana/ Opening circle
2:30-3:30 Stacy Talk (Energetic clearing and group healing)
3:30-4:30 Tahil Talk (Envisioning Relationships)
4:30-4:45 Viviana Talk and setup of vision boarding
4:45-6:15 Creation time
~Food will be served throughout the event~
6:15 - 6:45 Sharing of the boards
6:45-7 Closing Circle/Setting intentions



The Class Descriptions:
Clearing of Energy, "Catching Spirit", & Group Healing,
with Stacy Vajta:
What if you could “catch” Spirit’s idea of your life – what and where you
should put your energy into – as you step into the New Year?

New Years is a fantastic time to take stock of your life and look ahead.
Energetically, it’s a time when we begin to develop formand structure
around our dreams and creations as part of a natural creative cycle;
and so putting energy into what you want to create now and in the
months to comes lays a clear groundwork for you.
Envisioning your life as you move into 2013 in a way that allows Spirit
to show you what is of your highest vision can open the doors to a
magical year.  And, adding some energetic healing to release the past
and make room for what you create is a truly powerful process.
Stacy Vajta from Expanded Pathways will be leading you through this
powerful process beginning with envisioning your 2013 as you connect
deeply with your Spirit. She’ll be combining this with some powerful
group healing work to set the stage for the rest of the day as you weave
your highest vibration into your vision boards and dreams for the year
ahead.

Activating the Map: Breaking the Habits for Visioning in Your Life
& Relationships, with Tahil Gesyuk:
An interactive talk about how to own your challenges and use them as
stepping stones to use them for your vision to bloom.

Our vision is an activated map of anticipated challenges and obstacles
turned into stepping stones of opportunity bursting with creation and
innovation!  It is a verb with verve that makes our heart beat amplify with
every action. It also has the uncanny ability to magnetize the heart beats
that are pulled to the unique rhythm of the visions inspiration. We need to
be present to pulse of contractive and expansive cues our visions
expression in the world. We do this by training the habits and rituals that
will bring our vision into the world and mitigating and understanding the
rituals and habits that sabotage our vision.

Discovering the Vision: Creating Your Compass, with Viviana Lahrs:
A gently guided workshop to create your own vision board for 2013.

Traditional vision boards (aka dream boards, treasure maps) suggest
letting go of the board when done, put it away, forget about it, the
subconscious will hold onto the goals and visions you've created. To
some point this is true AND for more impact and success in your
visions becoming reality I guide you to take it a step further by analyzing
the board for patterns of core values, threads, and essences to guide
yourself as you move forward in you life after creating the board. Then
as decisions or opportunities arise, you can look back to your board and
see if it fits those directions, the board will become your own "compass"
to your actions and steps forward in 2013.

There will be ample time to create your boards during the workshop.
We will end the evening with a sharing of the boards, holding intentions
for the new year, activating the visions within the accountability of the
community circle.

**Suggested workshop preparation**: In the weeks approaching this
workshop begin collection images from magazines, books, random
flyers or postcards anything that catches your eye. Don't think much
about it, let your emotions and feelings guide you... Rather than looking
for that exact car you've been looking for, just gather any image that
pulls at you, inducing an "ahhh", "ooooo", "wow", "hmmm", "interesting",
"???", "!!!!" and grab it, put it in a collection basket or envelope to use at
the workshop. (Please note: There will magazines, and materials
available to you at the venue, so no worries if you don't bring any of your
own scraps and/or treasures.)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Facilitators Bios:

 

 

 

Stacy Vajta, owner of Expanded Pathways, is a Master Energy Healer and Intuitive with over 25 years of experience helping Indigos and other energy-aware folks to manage, and work with, the high vibrational information they're connected to — and all the complex energetic patterns that are tied to it — in a way that supports day-to-day living.


Stacy has studied with a variety of energetic modalities including: intuitive reading, chakra work, Light Language, Reiki, CranioSacral Therapy, Acupressure, Polarity work and more. These techniques along with the energetic understanding from years of working with clients and her own “downloads” from Guides and Spirit around the changing crystalline structures we hold and how the Nature Kingdom supports our growth and healing gives her a big tool kit for what is now a very focused approach to energy work, tapping into the body's subtle energies as well as multi-dimensional healing.


She works with people all over the globe via phone or Skype, supporting people in a really unique and comprehensive way, directing her healing attention to the physical, mental and spiritual. It's not uncommon for people to tell her they feel the energy work as they are working with long-distance...and that's because they’re working at the level of deep energetic change!

For more info about Stacy please visit: http://www.expandedpathways.com/


  Viviana Lahrs, co-creator of the Intimacy Forum. As a residential designer and feng shui consultant, massage therapist, yoga instructor, life coach, and mom, she expresses her joy and talents of producing collaborative holistic events, creating sacred space, and nurture in supporting community to have healthy extraordinary lives and relationships. Viviana facilitates monthly Women's Affection & Connection Circles, and is available for private coaching sessions. She can be reached directly at viviana@intimacyforumtraining.com.


Tahil Gesyuk, owner and course facilitator of the Intimacy Forum. Over the last 20 years, through his unique methods of synthesizing core concepts from both ancient traditions and modern research, he has helped over 1,000 couples create and maintain healthy, intimate relationships. Tahil facilitates monthly Affection & Connection Circles, Healer's Jams, and Holistic Faciliator Network Gatherings. He is also available for private coaching sessions and speaking engagements. Please contact tahil@intimacyforumtraining.com.


The Intimacy Forum produces events around affection and connection, bringing a unique synthesis of full sensory and full body learning around intimacy, connection and affection. We hold multiple circles and workshops monthly, in Berkeley and San Francisco, and workshops at summer festivals.

Tahil Gesyuk and Viviana Lahrs have a passion for bringing love, connection,and health into people's lives. With over 18 solid years of combined coaching experience, they are committed to bringing forth the radiance in each human being. As the founders and facilitators of the Intimacy Forum, Tahil Gesyuk and Viviana Lahrs are dedicated to teaching you the language of creating extraordinary relationships that impact the world in a loving and effective way.
For more info please visit: www.intimacyforumtraining.com

event.description:
Teacher: Maria Finn. About the class:
How do you set a tone with emails and memos?  How does sentence structure impact your message?  How can I make my written correspondence more effective?

Participants will learn to setting tones to persuade or inspire by choosing the best words. Textured structure that blends short, impactful sentences with long, flowing ones will make even an email something to admire.  Memos sent out with unified, coherent paragraphs will impress your co-workers to no end.

Much of the desire to write comes from wanting to have a voice in the world.  The basics of writing is also a system of logic, and mastering the basics like grammar, sentence structure and word choices that gives the confidence and the skill set to express your message.

Syllabus

- Purpose and intention of written communication: Why are you writing this and who is your audience
- What your punctuation says about you. The rules and -nuances of commas, periods and semi-colons.
- Sentence structure basics. Use sentence structure to create texture and rhythm.  Class participation 15 mins.
- Brainstorm/Setting Tone. We’ll do an exercise to choose the perfect words to set our tone. Work in pairs 15 mins
- Creating the perfect paragraph: A paragraph is a microcosm of the entire idea or proposal. It needs a beginning, a detailed middle and a conclusion. Class participation. 20 mins.

(Approximate times-1.5 hours for the class)

About Maria Finn:

Maria Finn is a regular contributor to Sunset Magazine and she also writes for The Wall Street Journal, Afar, The New York Times, Wine Spectator, Saveur, and Gastronomica, among others. She is the author of The Whole Fish, How Adventurous Eating of Seafood Will Make Your Healthier, Sexier and Help Save the Ocean” (TED Books 2012) Hold Me Tight and Tango Me Home (Algonquin 2010) and A Little Piece of Earth: How to Grow Your Own Food in Small Spaces (Rizzoli 2010). Her essays have been anthologized in The Best Food Writing 2006 and The Best Women's Travel Writing 2007. She also develops content for websites and social media marketing campaigns. She currently teaches Feature Writing at Stanford University.
